description.plain:
Formed in 1982 in New York City, Swans has been seen by many as one of the most beloved groups in the experimental rock sphere, constantly shifting musical genres. The band’s name was chosen due to real life swans being “…majestic, beautiful creatures. With really ugly temperaments.” Almost four decades of creating music, over 30 members in total throughout Swans' history, and countless amounts of side projects, the leader and conductor of the operation Michael Gira is an artist with little to no bounds.

The group is described as having three main eras:

Initially stemming from the New York no wave and industrial scene with Filth, Swans at first aimed to provide the harshest sound possible with their first four albums, with a reputation that live performances were so loud and brash it would make listeners projectile vomit.

Soon after, they aimed for a slightly melodic sound with the Gothic inspired Children of God, before developing subtle neo-folk landscapes from works such as White Light From the Mouth of Infinity and going all-in with post-rock and various tape loops on the band’s magnum opus, Soundtracks for the Blind.

Finally, the band has enjoyed a recent resurgence  in the 2010s with their reunion. They have received acclaim for their golden run of post-rock albums in this period, with the trilogy composing of The Seer, To Be Kind and The Glowing Man pushing the envelope of the band’s energy and sound to new limits. After The Glowing Man, the live band component split, leaving Gira as the only member, with 2019’s Leaving Meaning being his latest offering.

songs.title: Screen Shot

description.plain:
The introduction to To Be Kind begins with a sinister bass riff and slowly evolves to a chugging monster filled with clanging drums and sparkling guitars.

In  concert Bassist Christopher Pravdica plays the bass groove with a distortion pedal.

Lyrically, the song deals with the theme of everything being in the present, like a screen shot.

songs.full_title: Bring the Sun / Toussaint L’Ouverture by Swans
songs.title: Bring the Sun / Toussaint L’Ouverture

description.plain:
In an interview, Michael Gira was asked about what influenced “Toussaint L'Ouverture”:

Haiti is just a fulcrum for everything horrible and good. It has this intense magical belief which is pretty amazing. And it’s been the subject of exploitation and violence since the beginning. But it was also the site of the first successful slave revolt. That slave revolt resulted in Napoleon needing money very badly and consenting to the Louisiana Purchase which changed the course of modern history. It’s a terrible place that capitalist pigs have exploited into ruin. And Haitians, of course, have exploited each other like all humans.

In the same interview, he talked about his writing process for the song:

Frankly, [the song] grew out of playing music and needing some fucking words. I started screaming “Toussaint!” and I came up with words that fit the phenomenon. It’s a very odd way to make music and not how I work usually, but it’s how we’re working more now. We’ll have these pieces or atmospheres and I’ll start screaming and it will eventually become a finished piece rather than writing something on acoustic.

songs.full_title: I Was a Prisoner in Your Skull by Swans
songs.title: I Was a Prisoner in Your Skull
songs.title_with_featured: I Was a Prisoner in Your Skull

description.plain:
This song uses a spoken word recording taken by Jarboe’s father, who was an FBI agent. The speaker on the tape is a criminal, who is aware he is being recorded. The man taunts the people recording him, saying that they are sicker than he is for making it their job to follow and document his ‘crimes’, and that their careers are dependent on people like him committing crimes, and thus are reliant on him.

An alternate interpretation of this speech can involve living with a mental or physical disability, as the speaker describes situations in which a person needs assistance to finish everyday tasks. Coping with disabilities such as blindness is a recurring theme on the album.

songs.title: Oxygen

description.plain:
One of the most hard-hitting songs on the new Swans album, this song starts with a gnarly bass riff and ends with explosive guitar riffs and brass pops till the entire song explodes with shocking intensity.

Lyrically, the song is about a serious bout of asthma that Michael Gira suffered. He expanded on this in an interview:

Breathing and having a heartbeat are things that we’re completely not conscious of most of the time and take for granted. As someone who’s had severe bouts of asthma, I’m conscious of what it feels like to not be able to breathe. I was hospitalized for it. And this song was written after a particularly severe asthma attack. But now that I stopped smoking cigarettes, hopefully that will be gone.

songs.title: Blind

description.plain:
“Blind” serves as another angle of a “Failure”-like message, where a man, presumably Gira, starts strong, but naive, and withers in ambition as the passage of time goes by, until he becomes a failure (“Nothing has transpired”).

This song was added as a bonus track in the 2015 remaster of White Light From the Mouth of Infinity – it did not appear on the original 1991 release, instead, it was originally used as the final track of Michael Gira’s solo album, Drainland in 1995.

songs.title: The Seer

description.plain: “The Seer” is the monstrous thirty-two minute title track off of Swans' gigantic 2012 double album. The song itself is preceded by “The Wolf” and is followed by “The Seer Returns”, which features former Swans member Jarboe.

songs.title: To Be Kind

description.plain: Last song on To Be Kind. It embodies the feeling and experience of being a child. It remembers the innocent perspective of a kid, the days before one realizes the true nature of the world. Michael sees this innocence as a beautiful thing, its own artistic expression, like a song.

songs.lyrics:
[Verse 1]
And I, I've been lonely
And I, I've been blind
And I, I've learned nothing
So my hands are firmly tied
To the sinking lead weight of failure

[Verse 2]
I've worked hard all my life
Money slips through my hands
My face in the mirror tells me
It's no surprise that I am
Pushing the stone up the hill of failure

[Verse 3]
And they tempt me with violence
And they punish me with ideals
And they crush me with an image of my life
That's nothing but unreal
Except on the goddamned slaveship of failure

[Verse 4]
And I'll drown here trying
To get up for some air
But each time I think I breathe
I'm laid on with a double share
Of the punishing burden of failure
[Verse 5]
I don't deserve to be down here

And I,  I've learned one thing
You can't escape the beast
In the null and void pit of failure

[Verse 6]
When I get my hands on some money
I'll kiss its green skin
And I'll ask its dirty face
"Where the hell have ya been?"

[Verse 7]

songs.full_title: A Piece of the Sky by Swans (Ft. Akron/Family & Jarboe)
songs.title: A Piece of the Sky
songs.title_with_featured: A Piece of the Sky (Ft. Akron/Family & Jarboe)

description.plain:
In the demo version of this song found on the album “We Rose From Your Bed With The Sun in Our Head”; Michael Gira says “This is a song to our creator”.

Like so much of the Swans' music (especially their recent albums), this song has a transcendental urge behind it, a search for greater meaning. Ultimately, it is a search for God or something equivalent.

songs.full_title: Mother of the World by Swans
songs.title: Mother of the World

description.plain: The second song on The Seer seems to refer to the mother of The Seer himself. The instrumental kicks off with 4 minutes of pounding breathing and the voice of The Seer floating around, looming in the background. Until it breaks up and explodes to the narrator referencing sex. Perhaps the creation or birth of him as an entity. If not in the context of a concept the song could be taken as an otherworldly take on God and the creation/nurturing of man.

songs.title: Cloud of Unknowing

description.plain:
The namesake of a mystical text by an unknown author.

From Wikipedia: ‘The book counsels a young student to seek God, not through knowledge and intellection (faculty of the human mind), but through intense contemplation, motivated by love, and stripped of all thought. This is brought about by putting all thoughts and desires under a “cloud of forgetting”, and thereby piercing God’s cloud of unknowing with a “dart of longing love” from the heart. This form of contemplation is not directed by the intellect, but involves spiritual union with God through the heart:

“For He can well be loved, but he cannot be thought. By love he can be grasped and held, but by thought, neither grasped nor held. And therefore, though it may be good at times to think specifically of the kindness and excellence of God, and though this may be a light and a part of contemplation, all the same, in the work of contemplation itself, it must be cast down and covered with a cloud of forgetting. And you must step above it stoutly but deftly, with a devout and delightful stirring of love, and struggle to pierce that darkness above you; and beat on that thick cloud of unknowing with a sharp dart of longing love, and do not give up, whatever happens.”'

songs.title: The Sound

description.plain:
Following “Red Velvet Wound”, “The Sound” opens up the “Copper” half of “Soundtracks for the Blind” as another opus the album has to offer.

The song can be seen as the second “Helpless Child” (featured on the “Silver” side of the album) as they both share similiar lyrical themes of parental abuse and both feature an amazing building instrumental section.

songs.full_title: The World Looks Red/The World Looks Black by Swans
songs.title: The World Looks Red/The World Looks Black
songs.title_with_featured: The World Looks Red/The World Looks Black

description.plain:
Half of the lyrics of this song are taken from Sonic Youth’s “The World Looks Red”, which Gira wrote the lyrics for 33 years earlier. In fact, the relationship between Swans and Sonic Youth goes further than that, as Thurston Moore was a member of Swans at its founding in 1982, but quit very soon after, as Sonic Youth was becoming an increasingly big priority.

The other half of the song includes elements of spirituality and was written as an addition to the already used lyrics.

songs.title: Animus

description.plain:
The final track from the first CD of the legendary double album “Soundtracks For The Blind”. Despite the sombre and dark mood that the album carries, the album ends up with the hopes of an entity to make the protagonist find a motive.

Animus can be defined in both ways. An “animating spirit” or a strong dislike. Here Michael Gira is stating that his ultimate motivation will be the one that he ends up hating the most. In this song, an unknown person is the motivation, which is especially prevalent in the fourth verse.

Animus was also described by the psychologist Carl Jung as “the deposit, as it were, of all woman’s ancestral experiences of man – and not only that, he is also a creative and procreative being, not in the sense of masculine creativity, but in the sense that he brings forth something we might call… the spermatic word.”

Somewhere, through the frozen fields
Somewhere, beneath your pale and tender skin
Lies a house, absorbing fear and pain
Solar, red, contained, feeding on my dreams

[Verse 2]
Somewhere cold, inside the optic wire
Down where fingers and semen crack and bleed
There I will be, with my arms spread out and broken
Waiting for your breath, to animate my veins

[Verse 3]
We're not alone: all our thoughts are numbered
Malignant and cold, animal and hungry
But I will contain all that ever was or will be
Then I'll watch my skin erupt in a symphony of flames

[Refrain]
Screaming out your name
Screaming out

[Verse 4]
Why can't I hide inside your malleable electric face?
You'd suck away the pain and swallow down my sickest dreams
Now my body feels like snow spilling out the shattered screen
Where will we be then when all the fear and blood are gone?
Drained into one hundred million open children's mouths
[Refrain]
Screaming out your name

body.plain: This tells the story of a man that has fallen into depression after losing both the woman he loves and his childhood best friend.

songs.lyrics:
[Verse]
When, when we were young
We had no history, so nothing to lose
Meant we could choose, choose what we wanted then
Without any fear or thought of revenge
But then you grew old, and I lost my ambition
So I gained an addiction, to drink and depression
They are mine, my only true friends
And I'll keep them with me until the very end
I'd choose not to remember, but I miss your arrogance
And I need your intelligence, and your hate for authority
But now you're gone, I read it today
They found you in Spain, face down in the street
With a bottle in your hand and a wild smile on your face

description.plain:
“When Will I Return?” was written by Michael Gira to be sung by his wife Jennifer Gira, about an incident when she was sexually assaulted.

I wrote the song ‘When Will I Return? specifically for Jennifer Gira to sing. It’s a tribute to her strength, courage, and resilience in the face of a deeply scarring experience she once endured, and that she continues to overcome daily

songs.title: How They Suffer

description.plain:
“How They Suffer”, according to Michael Gira, serves as a tribute to the parents of both Gira and Jarboe, with the understanding that their generation of people were on their way out. There are two voice recordings present on the piece with a mournful synth melody in between them.

Gira’s father died around the time of arranging of this album (the voice recording is from 1986), while Jarboe’s mother was in a medical facility suffering from dementia.

songs.title: Killing for Company

description.plain:
“Killing for Company” was inspired by the murders commited by the serial killer Dennis Nilsen. He murdered at least twelve young men between 1978 and 1983 in London.

Nilsen would pick his victim, invite them to his house and then strangle it. He would keep the bodies and he would continue over the months to have sex with them, facepaint them or watch TV with them – his murders can be literally described as killing for company.

A coincidence in the album’s tracklist concerns his first murder. His first victim (who was 14 years old) was coaxed to his house with the promise of alcohol, which later became a pattern with his other victims. Dennis himself was also a fierce alcoholic.
“Alcohol the Seed” preceds this track, when literally, alcohol became the seed for his murder spree.

Nilsen died in prison on 12 May 2018.

songs.title: Coward

description.plain: In this song, the protagonist begs to be punished for being weak. The abuser is reluctant to hurt him though because he has dissipated into a shell of a person who is unrecognizable at this point, and how can you hurt someone deep down if there is nothing to hurt? He then tries to use his love for the abuser as incentive for the abuser to continue hurting him.

songs.title: YRP

description.plain:
In this song, Michael breaks down a day at his grandparents' house.

Okay, I know this song bio has caused some controversy, so let me explain my bad self. Michael, or in this case, Jarboe, is acting as the old guard, the “grandparents”, of society. The older generation is in power, and they have been corrupted by money. And we go into their “house”, and they work to recruit us into the grand tradition of corruption, and eventually we come to replace them, as the older, corrupt generation that rules over everything. We become their property.

songs.title: My Phantom Limb

description.plain: This song is the latest installment in Gira’s expression of his relationship with someone or something named Joseph. Gira has said many times over the years, most notably in relation to the album The Glowing Man, that there is a being of light in his mind that talks to him and that he often writes his songs from the perspective of this character(?). As he appears to be talking about himself to himself in such a disjointed, manic way, he appears to be trying to show the audience his mind while Joseph takes hold.

songs.title: Hypogirl

description.plain:
“The song begins with the sound of me having to get into character instantly as I had a commitment that night taking care of someone who needed me,” says Jarboe. “So I drove to the studio as quickly as I could, did the song and drove back. The sound you hear first is me reacting after I shot back old whiskey belonging to my father. I had grabbed it going out the door when Michael called me to the studio to sing. It was literally speed to the studio, shoot back strong whiskey, perform that vocal, drive back home as fast as I can.”

Source: http://magnetmagazine.com/2016/08/16/magnet-classics-the-making-of-swans-soundtracks-for-the-blind/

songs.title: Red Velvet Corridor

description.plain:
“Red Velvet Corridor” draws the listener in through swirling synth patterns, drones, tape loops and the twinkling of triangles, establishing the eerie and experimental themes of the entire album and especially the next track.

The color red is commonly associated with blood and danger, and the name of the track could be serving as a warning to the listener. Corridors also serve as entrances and passageways, which ties in with it being the first track of the album.

A red velvet corridor may be a metaphor for a birth canal that a child passes through in order to be born, with the album’s opening track signifying someone being born into the world. Fitting with the album’s title, a newborn child is blind until it exits the red velvet corridor that is its mother’s womb.

Its counterpart is the beginning of the second disc, “Red Velvet Wound.” These two songs sample each other.

songs.title: Jim

description.plain:
“Jim” is about musician Jim (J.G.) Thirlwell, creator and principle member of the band Foetus. In an interview with The Quietus, Michael Gira said:

This song is a tribute to my old friend, the promethean, eruptive genius, JG Thirlwell [Foetus, Wiseblood]. I won’t explain how the words refer to Jim specifically, but listening to his music lately gave me hope to continue working and living myself. I was really happy when we found a groove for this song, so natural. I see this groove as containing a seed of something that will continue into the next SWANS album.

Nietzschean themes of a will to power, delusioned masses, advancing ‘beyond good and evil’, and war pervade the lyrics.

songs.title: Annaline

description.plain:
“Annaline” sets the difference of tone leaving meaning. presents from its harsh predecessors straight from the get-go, with all the markings of a chamber folk love song with soft, ambient and subdued textures. The song is quite similar in this respect to “Evangeline” from Gira’s past project Angels of Light.

“Annaline” probably has the most extensive history of the songs on the album. It was the sole original demo song exclusive to I Am Not This, a limited edition compilation album recorded in 2016 just before the The Glowing Man was released. In early 2019, it also appeared on Swans' demo album for leaving meaning, which was entitled What Is This?, in the same form.

songs.title: Minus Something

description.plain:
This is the same voice from the recording on “The Beautiful Days”.

The words spoken, their lethargic delivery, and the eerie synths building in the background gives this track a heightened feeling of dissociation, as if the person talking has become aware that they have numbed themselves and therefore lost part of themselves (“Minus something”) In order to get through their daily life.

songs.full_title: I Love You This Much by Swans
songs.title: I Love You This Much

description.plain: Appearing on the second disc of Soundtracks for the Blind, “I Love You This Much” is an immensely eerie track in two sections: the song begins with synthesized squelches and near-screaming interjections, as well as a low drone sample, most of which are heard on “Volcano,” a song that appears on the first disc of Soundtracks for the Blind. The song then devolves into a quiet pitch, and moves into a loud, raucous section with samples heard from “Lavender” on the live album Swans Are Dead: Live ‘95-'97 and “Lavender Girl” from Jarboe’s Swans-related album Sacrificial Cake.

description.plain:
The eighth track on Children of God portrays a man contemplating murdering a child as a sacrifice to his god.

The track was likely inspired by a biblical story in which God requests that the prophet Abraham sacrifice his own son, Isaac, as a test of his devotion.

songs.title: You Know Nothing

description.plain:
You Know Nothing is an oddly optimistic song by Swans, very pensive and beautiful, with images of love and hope and a very glowing feeling. You Know Nothing sounds rude or insulting, meant to hurt someone, but really, You Know Nothing is about how we forge our own lives and love, and our fate is in our hands. Very lovely from a band that went from “SATISFY THE DOG” “FLEX YOUR MuScLeS” and of course “USE SEX FOR CONTROL” to “And I was told that your eyes
Would shine a light up into space”

songs.title: 93 Ave. B Blues

description.plain: 93 Ave B. is the address of a building in New York City around the area where Michael Gira lived during the early 80s. He talks about it in a Rolling Stone Interview, “I lived on 6th Street and Avenue B – was mostly abandoned buildings, gunfire every night; machine-gun fire, in fact. Some buildings were just piles of rubble. Other buildings taken over by dope dealers and were mainly places to sell heroin. Lots of crime. It was a much different city than what it is now.”

songs.title: Mellothumb

description.plain: A droning, slow, acoustic track appearing on the first disc of Soundtracks for the Blind, “Mellothumb” provides a momentary respite between the pummeling dance-track “Volcano” and the atmospheric, destructive track “All Lined Up.” “Mellothumb” begins with a somber acoustic strum over droning synthesizers, eventually devolving into sampled noise, fading out into “All Lined Up.”

songs.title: Amnesia (leaving meaning.)

description.plain:
This version of Amnesia is a rearrangement of the identically-named Swans song Amnesia from their 1992 album Love Of Life. It presents itself as a slower, softer and a very symphonic song compared to its fierce post-punk counterpart, yet still retains its impact. There are minor lyric changes between the two.

Michael Gira has had a weird fascination and attachment to the song, and experimented with a new arrangement of Amnesia on tour since early 2016, soon after the release of The Glowing Man.

I’m using the words from the song “Amnesia” (from 1992’s Love of Life) but the music is completely different.

This was further developed throughout his solo tours afterward, becoming a common opener of his 2018 tour. In a similar vein, “God Damn The Sun” (from The Burning World) was considered for a rearrangement for the album, and is present on the original sketch list for What Is This?, but was dropped for unknown reasons.

songs.title: Her

description.plain:
“Her” is a simple love song from Michael Gira to Jarboe, split in two halves by a brief, but harsh breakdown. Gira and Jarboe had been collaborating for years at this point, and a relationship had bloomed between the two, which is why this song was formed.

The second half of the song uses a cassette recording taken by Jarboe’s father, an FBI agent who recorded her phone conversations without her knowledge. More cassette recordings belonging to her father of unknown people and origin were used throughout 1996’s Soundtracks For The Blind.

songs.lyrics:
[Verse]
I'll walk with you
Through space and time
And when sleep is near
I will fold you in
I'll disappear with you
In clear blue flames
And when our time arrives
We will slide through space
Do do do do do do, do do do do do do, do do, mmm
Do do do do do do, do do do do do do, do do, mmm

[Outro: Jarboe]
Trying to think of things to say, and really, where to begin. Uh, the summer's been pretty good so far, I'm looking forward to the day, uh, that is, this summer when, uh Charlie will be out of camp. I don't even know if you know about Charlie, but I have a, uh, kinda of a.. friend, huh, named Charlie Bewman, uh, he's real wild, uh, you would like him if you met him, and uh, he's in this camp. Sounds like a... rehabilitation center for juvenile delinquents, the way he writes about it, some of the jobs they have him do. But he's gonna be out, uh, few more weeks, and, since he's out, we're, uh, gonna really live it up. Maybe you heard, I, I doubt it, but maybe you heard about this big bash they had last weekend, Atlanta International Pop Festival. Janis Joplin, The Who, and, uh, you know, apparently, uh, all the people who were in the Monterey Pop movie, all the big guys, you know, Johnny Rivers, all the big stars, big folk people, uh big soul people, everybody, it was dandy, I didn't get to go to it though, sadly enough. And this afternoon The Grateful Dead was playing at Piedmont Park, four o' clock. But, uh I'm afraid I'll miss out on that too. One thing that sounds groovy, Charlie is a great drummer. He has some friends that are very musically inclined, and I can play the organ a bit, as you know, uh, I enjoy singing. So, um, we're gonna see if we can maybe get up a group!EmbedShare URLCopyEmbedCopy

songs.title: Surrogate 2

description.plain: Funny enough, “Surrogate 2” appears on Soundtracks for the Blind much before its supposed predecessor, “Surrogate Drone.” The two tracks share very similar structures: “Surrogate 2” is made up of a constant, steady drone, with little interjected synths and tape-loops here or there, eventually devolving into a noisy, sampled loop that segues in the next track, “How They Suffer.”

songs.title: Surrogate Drone

description.plain: A fitting end to Swans' monumental album Soundtracks for the Blind, “Surrogate Drone” is structured exactly how its title implies: a long, heavy drone over the span of two minutes, eventually devolving into a looped hi-hat from a drum machine, which quickly slows to nothing, almost like the stopping of a tape being played.

songs.title: Secret Friends

description.plain: An instrumental track in two sections, “Secret Friends” begins with a light, poignant melody played on a synthesizer or sampler, and eventually moves into a second, darker section with a sinister acoustic guitar playing over the synth, with Michael Gira moaning a faint, reverb-ed melody in the background. The more poignant tone provides an excellent segue into the majesty and beauty of its succeeding track, “The Final Sacrifice.”

songs.lyrics:
Drink to me only with thine eyes

Or leave a kiss within the cup
And I'll not ask for wine
The thirst that from the soul doth rise

Not so much honoring thee
As giving it a hope that there
It could not withered be
But thou thereon did only breathe
And sent it back to me
Since when it grows and smells, I swear
Not of itself, but theeEmbedShare URLCopyEmbedCopy

songs.title: Eden Prison

description.plain:
Swans frontman Michael Gira said of this song:

It refers back to childhood memories of me being in jail when I was a kid. I was hitchhiking across Europe, and I ended up in Israel, where I was arrested for selling hashish. I spent four and a half months in jail. It was a pretty formative experience.

Apparently, there is a prison with the exact name in New Zealand, but Gira was unaware of this at the time of writing the song.

songs.lyrics:

[Verse 3]

Nobody knows you feel
Go further back inside you
Where nothing else is real
Now throw yourself into a pool
Of silence you can see
[Refrain]
And hold the mirror before your eyes
And light the white light
It's the sound of freedom

[Verse 4]
Now time is just a picture
That moves before your eyes
And every lie that I believe
Is falsely compromised
And this is not a sound
And we are not alive

In someone else's mind
And the ground we walk is sacred
And every object lives
And every word we speak
Will punish or forgive
And the light inside your body
Will shine through history
Set fire to every prison
Set every dead man free
And the air we're breathing now
We breathed a million times
The darkest dreams we dreamed
Were dreamed by other minds
So take us to the water
And take us to the sound
And wash my soul away
Where it never can be found
[Verse 5]
And the white light that surrounds us
Is the sound of freedom pounding
And the ground that opens up
It spits the fire from freedom's mouth
And the concrete, glass and steel
Break with a freedom you can feel
And the wind that blows through Heaven
It screams the sound of freedom
And the violence that destroys
Is the birth of freedom singing
And the lovers in the field
They make the sound of freedom bleeding
And the pain that eats my mind
Is the shout of freedom's life
And the fire that burns this city
Is the white light in freedom's eye
And the white light is the sound

[Refrain]
Yes it is the sound
Of freedom1EmbedShare URLCopyEmbedCopy

songs.title: Stupid Child

description.plain:
“Stupid Child” seems to describe a twisted infantile-like relationship, with reference to self-harm and abuse.

The song’s lyrics and title have a lot of parallels to “Helpless Child”, a more lyrically dense song that would appear a good 10 years later on the band’s final album in their original run, Soundtracks for the Blind.

The song usually ended live with a repetition of “helpless, helpless…” Very chilling.

description.plain:
Info from the booklet:

This was born, after much trial and error, out of the song “Deliquescing,” which itself was born out of “The World Looks Red / The World Looks Black.” The performance recorded for the album marks the first time it found an actual shape.

This performance was recorded at Huxley’s, Berlin, October 18th 2016.
